newsitem.title: GERMANY: German minister says EU may not block Boeing.
newsitem.headline: German minister says EU may not block Boeing.

text.p: German Foreign Minister Klaus Kinkel on Wednesday that there were indications that the European Commission would not immediately block a merger of U.S. aerospace groups Boeing and McDonnell Douglas.

In an interview with German Radio, Kinkel said he was certain the United States would try to avoid a trade war with Europe over the merger, despite that fact that both sides have remained tough on the issue.

Kinkel said EU Competition Commissioner Karel Van Miert informed European foreign ministers about the status of negotiations over the Boeing merger and said that "he was of the opinion that we first need to analyse the situation".
He also noted progress after the United States appeared to show some flexiblility on a controversial practice of exclusivity in contracts with the U.S. aerospace giants.
"There are indications that it will not come to a rejection of the merger by the Commission," Kinkel said, adding: "But this has not been decided."
U.S. President Bill Clinton said on Tuesday there was still time to work out an agreement to avoid an "unfortunate trade conflict" with Europe over the merger.

Clinton told White House reporters he had focused on the issue over the past three days "and will continue to do so. I think there's a way to work this out and I'm hopeful that by Wednesday when the (European) Commission meets, an agreement will have been reached."

Europeans are concerned that a newly enlarged Boeing -- which already accounts for 60 percent of the sales of large commercial aircraft -- would have a massive competitive edge over Airbus Industrie, the European aircraft consortium.
